results: Hybrid subconvexity bounds for twists of GL2 × GL2 L-functions
Improved bounds using delta method and Voronoi summation formula
title: Hybrid Subconvexity Bounds for Twists of GL_2× GL_2 L-functions.pdf
abstract: . In this paper, we prove hybrid subconvexity bounds for GL2 × GL2 Rankin– Selberg L-functions twisted by a primitive Dirichlet character χ modulo a prime power, in the t and depth aspects. 1. Introduction The subconvexity problem for general L-functions is one of the central questions in analytic number theory and it has many applications in number theory. Let f and g be holomorphic or Maass cusp forms for SL2(Z) with normalized Fourier coeﬃcients λf(n) and λg(n) respec- tively. Let χ be a primitive Dirichlet character of prime power conductor pκ with p prime. The GL2 × GL2 × GL1 Rankin–Selberg L-function is deﬁned by L (s, f × g × χ) = L(2s, χ2) ∞ X n=1 λf(n)λg(n)χ(n) ns , for Re(s) > 1. And this L-function has an analytic continuation to the whole complex plane. The subconvexity problem for GL2 × GL2 × GL1 L-functions is to obtain a bound of the form L 1 2 + it, f × g × χ  ≪(pκ(|t| + 1))1−δ+ε with 0 ≤δ ≤1. The convexity bounds correspond to the bounds with δ = 0, which follow from the func- tional equation and the Phragm´en–Lindel¨of convexity principle. The Lindel¨of hypothesis is the statement with δ = 1. The literature on the subconvexity problem is rich and the ﬁrst result can be traced back over 100 years ago. For the GL1 case, Weyl [24] proved a subconvexity bound for Riemann zeta function. Burgess [6] proved a subconvexity bound for Dirichlet L-functions. For GL2 case, see Michel–Venkatesh [21] and the references therein. Many progress on GL3 L-functions has been made in the past ten years (see [3], [17], [19], [20], [11], etc.). Subconvexity for GL2 ×GL2 L-functions have been solved by many number theorists. For the t-aspect, see Bernstein–Reznikov [2], Acharya–Sharma–Singh [1], Blomer–Jana–Nelson [4], Huang–Sun–Zhang [10]. For the depth aspect, see Sun [22]. 2010 Mathematics Subject Classiﬁcation. 11F66 . Key words and phrases. Hybrid subconvexity, twists, Delta method, GL2 × GL2 Rankin–Selberg L- functions.
